input: Write a short biography of Bill Nye.
output: William Sanford "Bill" Nye (born 1955) is an American author, actor, educator, and scientist. He is best remembered for hosting the television series _"Bill Nye the Science Guy,"_ on which he presented scientific ideas in a playful manner. Nye has founded or co-founded several education- and science-related organizations, including the Planetary Society and the Nye/Marshall Foundation. He has also authored several books on science. A vocal proponent of science and education, Nye was nicknamed "America's science ambassador" by Scientific American. In 2022, he was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives.

input: Write a short biography of Bill Nye.
output: Bill Nye (born 1955) is a US engineer, comedian, TV host, scientific communicator, and author. He grew up in Seattle, WA, and attended the University of Washington. Nye began creating science educational material in the 1980's, when he and his "Bill Nye the Science Guy" set, a team of two actors and two scientists, won Emmy Awards for its videos. He appeared as a host on PBS's Bill Nye the Science Guy from 1993-94 and co-hosted the show Clifford's Puppyhood from 2000-03. Nye published his first children's book in 1998 and his first full-length nonfiction book for adults in 2015. Nye has been involved in several US climate policy initiatives.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 BCE) was a Roman general, statesman, and reformer. An orator and writer, he was a key figure in the history of ancient Rome. He served as chief administrator of Rome, reorganizing the Roman Kingdom into the Roman Republic after defeating his political rival, Pompey, in the civil war that ended with the Battle of Pharsalus. Caesar was elected Consul three times before dictating an ambitious reform policy under the title of Second Triumvirate. The Senate and Mark Antony became increasingly suspicious of Caesar's ambitions, and in 44, he was assassinated.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100 BCE- 44 BCE) was a famous Roman leader and general who conquered much of Europe and led the transition from the Roman Republic to the Roman Empire. He led the invasion of Gaul (modern-day France and Belgium) and Spain. He returned to Rome to face tribunal charges in 59 BCE to overthrow the democratic governors. He gained great power as a member of the Roman elite, serving as governor of Gaul in 58 BCE to 50 BCE, followed by governor of Hispania (Iberia). As a political ally of the Roman elite, Caesar faced tribunal charges in 59 BCE for high crimes against the Roman people but won the majority of votes and became the dictator of Rome in 53 BCE. In 45 BCE, he tried to amass power by becoming emperor, but he was killed during a rebellion.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100 BC-44 BC) was an statesman, general, and ruler of Rome who won a Civil War and became dictator for life. Born into a patrician family, he served as a general in the Gallic Wars, distinguishing himself for his talent and boldness. After deposing several Roman kings, he was made consul and dictator. output: Gaius Julius Caesar (100-44 BC) was a politician and general during the late Roman Republic. Seen as a hero by some, an usurper by others, his assassination in 44 BC precipitated a series of civil wars. input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 B.C.E.) was a Roman general and dictator who played a decisive role in the conquest of Gaul and the formation of the Roman Empire. When King Philip of the Mithridatid Kingdom died, a civil war began in 78 B.C.E., and in 77 C.E. Caesar was appointed leader of the war. He conquered the Gauls and formed the Roman Republic into an empire, naming himself Consul Governor in 48 B.C.E. In 44 B.C.E. Caesar was assassinated by his political enemies. His nephew, Octavius, took command and formed the Roman Empire under the first emperor, Augustus.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 BC) was a Roman general, statesman, and author who conquered Gaul and much of Germany. He was made consul and proconsul in 60 BC and defeated the Parthian Empire in 53-52 BC. A rivalry with Pompey and Crassus resulted in the Liberatores' civil war; Caesar became dictator in 46 and consul for life in 27. His reign was marked by repeated civil unrest and assassination attempts. In 44 BC, a conspiracy led by Gaius Cassius Longinus and Gaius Julius Brutus successfully stabbed him in the Capitolium; he died three days later. Rome renamed September 14 after Caesar, as did France in 1802, though his actual birthday is not known. Caesar is regarded as one of the most celebrated leaders of the ancient world, with a reputation exceeded only by Alexander the Great, and his conquest of Gaul has become a major influence on European literature and culture.

input: Write a short biography of Howard Zinn.
output: Howard Zinn (1922-2010) was a social historian who wrote landmark books on American history. A bombardier during World War II, Zinn's subsequent career included a stint teaching in a small Massachusetts high school and involvement in the Civil Rights movement. Although he held a doctorate, Zinn rebelled against the traditional perspective of American history as a story of "bigwigs and battles." He worked on his "people's history" and "alternative" textbook, A People's History of the United States, for years. Revised constantly, the book became a national bestseller. A documentary, A People's History of the United States, built off the popularity of the book. A professor at Boston University, Zinn was active in anti-Iraq War protests in the 2000s.

input: Write a short biography of Dian Fossey.
output: Dian Fossey (1932-1985) was a self-taught primatologist credited with studying mountain gorillas in what is now the Virunga Volcanic National Park. Fossey had been trained in physical anthropology and had worked for Jane Goodall before launching her own research in 1967. She spent 18 years studying the gorillas, suffering repeated attacks from the animals, including several instances of brutal assaults and stabbings. Fossey became famous for her work on the gorillas and was named among the "100 people of the century" by Time Magazine. In 1981, Fossey was murdered, and one of her killers pinned the crime on her lover, Klaus von Bulow. Another was convicted of murder and released in 2015.

input: Write a short biography of The Rolling Stones.
output: The Rolling Stones is an English rock band, founded in London in 1962. Originally called the Rollin' Stones, the band was the first in which Mick Jagger and Keith Richards were together. Their earliest incarnation featured Brian Jones and Ian Stewart on guitar and piano, respectively; Stuart "Woody" Wood and Dick Taylor on bass; and Mick Avory on drums. Their early sound, inspired by Chicago blues, consisted of a stripped-down electric guitar. Their first hit, "The Last Time," was released in 1964. The band has continued to tour, releasing their 30th studio album, BLUES & LONESOME, in 2022. The band has sold more than 300 million records worldwide. The Stones have been active for six decades; their longest-lasting members are Jagger and Richards.

input: Write a short biography of The Rolling Stones.
output: The Rolling Stones are an English rock band formed in 1962. The Stones are regarded as one of the world's greatest and longest-lived rock bands. Begun by guitarist Keith Richards and bassist Brian Jones, the group blended Chicago blues with London rock and pop music to produce its own genre, rolling into the heart of Swinging London. Their influences included blues artist Muddy Waters, Mick Jagger's friend and fellow bluesman/rock artist, American bluesman and singer Buddy Guy. The band quickly built a reputation for their electric live performances and raucous antics while also gaining a name for their musical skills and the group quickly became popular, performing sold-out shows. By the mid-1960s, Jagger and Richards were leading an increasingly rambunctious group. Their musical style and lyrical focus changed from the "British Invasion," where their music came to include blues, rhythm and blues, psychedelia and hard rock and blues rock.

input: Write a short biography of The Rolling Stones.
output: The Rolling Stones are an English rock band originally founded in 1962. They quickly rose to prominence in the UK and US with a string of hits in the 1960s. A long run of successful UK and US records extended into the 1970s, and their 1981 US hits compilation "Greatest Hits" was one of the best-selling albums of all time. The band continues to sell out stadium tours around the world. Lead vocalist Mick Jagger is the only remaining member of the original group; guitarist Keith Richards and bassist Bill Wyman retired from official duties in 1975, with Wyman leaving and pianist Ian Stewart passing away in 1985. Drummer Charlie Watts has been the sole constant through the band's history, and the current lineup includes guitarist Ronnie Wood, keyboardist Chuck Leavell, and former guitarist Mick Taylor (1975-1993), as well as original drummer and lyricist Bill Wyman.

The group has achieved multiple gold and platinum albums and earned 9 number 1 songs on the US Hot 100. The Rolling Stones have sold over 200 million albums, including 40 million between 1971 to 1974 alone.

input: Write a short biography of Michael Jordan.
output: Michael Jordan (1963-2020) was an American basketball player well known for his high-scoring feats. Jordan played for the Chicago Bulls and the Charlotte Hornets in a remarkable career that began in 1984. He was named Most Valuable Player in the NBA six times and won six championships with the Chicago Bulls beginning in 1991. input: Write a short biography of Jane Goodall.
output: Jane Goodall (born 1934) is an ethologist and primatologist who was the first scientist to study wild chimpanzees. After reading an article on chimps in 1955, Goodall was inspired to work with animals after graduating from Oxford on a fellowship. She received a grant from UNESCO to study chimpanzees in Gombe, Tanzania, launching a decades-long study of their behavior and interactions with people. Goodall advocated for animal welfare and an international park system to help preserve habitat. She has since founded many organizations, including the Jane Goodall Institute and Roots and Shoots.

input: Write a short biography of Jane Goodall.
output: Jane Goodall (born 1934) is a British primatologist, ethologist, anthropologist and UN Messenger of Peace. She is best known for her research on chimpanzees in Gombe Stream National Park, Tanzania. After being inspired by the 1960 film _Monkey Business_, she worked for the British colony in Uganda, and then moved to Gombe in 1960. Conducting behavioral observations in the same forest for over half a century, Goodall revolutionized the field of primate behavioral ecology, proving the ability of the chimpanzee to adapt to new environments and using non-humans to better understand our own human societies as well.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra VII Philopator (69  BC- 30 BC) was the last ruler of the Ptolemaic dynasty in Egypt. She ruled along with her father, Ptolemy XII, from 80  BC until his death in 51 BC. Later, Cleopatra ruled with her brothers and their father Ptolemy XIII as co-regent of Egypt. She became the sole ruler of Egypt in 51  BC. Cleopatra famously seduced Mark Antony and had three children with him, later committing suicide by snake venom after he divorced her to marry his second wife, Octavia the Younger, the sister of the Roman Empress. Her death sparked the Roman-Egyptian War, which marked the end of Ptolemaic dynasty in Egypt. She is regarded by modern scholars as one of the most powerful women of antiquity due to her role in the series of civil wars known as the Final War of the Roman Republic.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra (69-30 BCE) was the last pharaoh of Ancient Egypt, ruling at the time of its final conflict with Rome. The eldest daughter of Ptolemy XIII and Cleopatra VII, her father appointed her and her brother joint monarchs at the age of 11, but he was murdered in an orchestrated coup by her brothers. The young pharaoh had to abdicate, but regained control after her brother's death and briefly reunited Egypt with Ptolemaic rule. After Julius Caesar's conquest of Rome, he visited Cleopatra and formed a political alliance, which was dissolved when his rival Mark Antony married her. In 31 BCE, the Roman leaders assassinated Cleopatra, marking the end of Ancient Egypt.

Cleopatra then married their uncle, King Ptolemy XIV, making him her co-ruler until she had him killed and took the throne herself. She ruled Egypt with Julius Caesar, Marc Antony, and her brothers. She was famous for her beauty and political skill. Following a victory against her rival and lover, Mark Antony, she killed herself for fear of losing her son to Octavian, Caesar's heir and successor.

input: Write a short biography of The Weeknd.
output: Abel Makkonen Tesfaye (born 1990), known professionally as The Weeknd, is a Canadian singer, songwriter, and record producer. Raised in Toronto, he moved to the United States at seventeen. Abandoning a college music program he pursued a career as a recording artist, producing songs and posting them on Myspace. He broke into the pop charts in 2011 with the EP Trilogy, which reached number one on the Billboard R&B/Hip Hop charts. The Weeknd's debut album, Kiss Land (2013), reached number one on the Billboard R&B and rap charts. His second album, Beauty Behind the Madness (2015), hit #1 on the Billboard 200 and won a Grammy for Best Urban Contemporary Album in 2016. He released the third album, Starboy, in 2016. The most popular song on the album was "Starboy," a multi-platinum hit that won a Grammy for Best R&B Performance. By 2019 The Weeknd had won a dozen Grammys.

input: Write a short biography of The Weeknd.
output: Abel Makkonen Tesfaye (better known by his stage name The Weeknd) (born 1990) is a Canadian-Ethiopian singer, songwriter, and producer. His first two albums, House of Balloons and Thursday, established him as a star. After taking a hiatus in December 2019, he released the singles "Heartless," "Blinding Lights" and "Negative" in late 2020. He's won three Grammys and been included on Billboard's Artist of the Decade list.

input: Write a short biography of Aretha Franklin.
output: Aretha Franklin (1942-2018) was an American singer and musician. Known as the "Queen of Soul," she began performing with her father, a Baptist minister and vocalist, in church at age 10. Signing with Columbia Records as a teen, her 1967 hit "Respect" went to number one and became an anthem for the American civil rights movement. As a songwriter, Franklin won her first Grammy for the album I Never Loved a Man the Way I Love You. She won 18 Grammy Awards during her career and was one of 31 artists inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. Franklin was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian award, in 2005. She was the second female artist to be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and the American Music Awards' highest honor, the President's Award, in 2009. She performed at 14 inaugurations from JFK to Obama, and in 2018, became the first woman to be inducted into the Memphis Music Hall of Fame

input: Write a short biography of Wangari Maathai.
output: Wangari Maathai (1940-2011) was a Kenyan biologist, environmentalist, politician and Nobel Prize winner. Maathai founded the Green Belt Movement, an environmental non-profit organization. It trained over 90,000 rural women to plant trees on communal lands, helping to turn around Kenya's deforestation epidemic. The movement inspired a global "green revolution" among students, workers and the poor. Maathai was co-recipient of the 2004 Nobel Peace Prize, alongside Ralph Johnson Falknor Jr. She became Kenya's first female Deputy Speaker in 2003 and ran for President in 2005. In 2011, Maathai died of cancer.

input: Write a short biography of Wangari Maathai.
output: Wangari Maathai (1940-2011) was the first African woman elected to head the United Nations General Assembly and a conservationist who developed a grassroots reforestation movement that helped to protect land from the effects of deforestation. Maathai studied at the University of Nairobi and worked as a veterinary assistant before earning a master's degree from the University of Pittsburgh. In 1977, she founded the Green Belt Movement, focusing on women's rights and reforestation. In the 1990s, she headed the East African campaign against the construction of a toxic waste dump near Mount Kilimanjaro; it was later buried under a mountain of petition signatures. Maathai received the 2004 Nobel Peace Prize and founded a 100-acre park in Nairobi.

input: Write a short biography of Anne Frank.
output: Anne Frank (1929-1945) was the Jewish diarist who wrote about her time hiding from the Nazis with her family in Amsterdam's "Secret Annexe" during World War II. Inspired by Alexander Miller's book, The Diary of a Young Girl (published in 1947 after her death), Frank wrote her own diary entries from 1942 to 1944. The book has become a literary classic that has inspired generations of readers. Frank wrote about her relationships with her sister, her parents, friends, and even one of her parents' former employees with whom they lived during the war. Her diary became influential in spreading knowledge about Nazi racism and anti-Semitism, and continues to influence young authors to write, in the face of adversity. Frank died on March 30, 1945, in Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. In 2020, a Dutch court ruled that it was no longer practical to find the remains of Frank and the other victims who were buried in the camp's crematorium.

input: Write a short biography of Anne Frank.
output: Anne Frank (1929-1945) was a Jewish girl from Amsterdam who wrote an acclaimed diary of life under Nazi occupation. Her parents were German-Jewish refugees who fled to Holland in 1933. Anne grew up in Amsterdam, becoming a talented young writer and social activist. In 1942, her family went into hiding in Amsterdam during the roundup of Jews, led by Otto Frank, her father. Anne and her sister went into hiding with four other people. They were discovered in August 1944 and deported to concentration camps. Only Otto survived the war and in 1950, he began his efforts to publish the diary, which went on to worldwide best-seller status. In 1955, the last member of the Frank family, Otto, published an expanded edition, making Anne's story widely known. A play and film have also been made of her life.

input: Write a short biography of Anne Frank.
output: Anne Frank (1929-1945) was a Jewish diarist whose journal from the years of World War II is considered one of the world's most important memoirs of the era. Born in Frankfurt am Main, she was later sent to Amsterdam for safety with her parents, sisters, and many extended family members. Anne kept a diary while hiding with her family in the attic of a Jewish supporter's home. Her writings reflected the daily life of the group and showed the fear and hope that people had after the war was announced. Despite being imprisoned, Frank remained optimistic. She was killed in the Nazi concentration camp of Bergen-Belsen at age 15. Her diary was published in 1947; it has been translated into more than 70 languages, and has sold more than 30 million copies.

input: Write a short biography of Audre Lorde.
output: Audre Glidden Lorde (1934-1992) was an activist and writer who worked to improve the conditions for African-Americans and other minorities in the US. After graduating from Hunter College, she earned a master's degree in library science before receiving an MFA from Cornell. Lorde joined the feminist movement in 1969. She founded the Kitchen Table: Women of Color Press in 1980 to publish works by women of color. Her novel _Zami: A New Spelling of My Name_ in 1982. Lorde died of cancer in 1992. Her novels _Song of Salt and Blood_ and _Zahra_ were posthumously published by Toni Morrison.

input: Write a short biography of Audre Lorde.
output: Audre Lorde (1934-1992) was a prominent Afro-American activist and writer. A breast cancer survivor, Lorde dedicated much of her work to addressing the disproportional health and legal treatment of women of color. She also published poetry and essays focused on social issues, often through an intersectional lens. Lorde faced death threats in the 1960s and 1970s, and was disowned by her family, but continued to speak out. She won a National Book Award in 1978 and a MacArthur Fellowship in 1991. Her papers are now available online.

input: Write a short biography of Neil Armstrong.
output: Neil Armstrong (1930-2012) was the first man to step onto the moon. A naval aviator in the Korean War, he joined NASA in 1962 and was selected to train for the Gemini program. In 1969, Armstrong and fellow astronaut Edwin "Buzz" Aldrin landed on the moon in the Apollo 11 mission. Armstrong took a picture later that day, and famously radioed back to Earth: "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind." He spent the next 30 years as an aerospace engineer, test pilot, and lecturer before dying of cancer in 2012. Armstrong is often remembered as a humble man with a passion for exploration.

He flew several different kinds of planes as a civilian pilot and worked for the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics. In 1962, he became a NASA astronaut. On July 20, 1969, the Apollo 11 mission landed on the moon. Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin were the first two people to walk on the moon, while Michael Collins orbited in the Command Module. Armstrong spent 2 hours and 31 minutes walking around the surface of the moon. An American hero, he commanded the Skylab 1 mission shortly thereafter and taught engineering at the University of Cincinnati.

input: Write a short biography of Neil Armstrong.
output: Neil Armstrong (1930-2012) was an American astronaut and first person to set foot on the Moon on July 20, 1969. A navy pilot, Armstrong was selected for NASA's Project Gemini in 1963. His first time in space was on Gemini 8, the first mission with two people onboard. After joining Apollo 11, Armstrong guided the Lunar Module Eagle to a landing on the Moon's Sea of Tranquility. The world watched the lunar landing on television, one of the most significant historical events. After leaving NASA, Armstrong served as a professor of Aerospace Engineering and History at the University of Cincinnati.

input: Write a short biography of Mark Twain.
output: Samuel Langhorne Clemens (1835-1910), better known as Mark Twain, was an American author and humorist. His two best-known books are The Adventures of Tom Sawyern (1876) and The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn (1885). Other novels include Life on the Mississippi (1883) and Innocents Abroad (1869). Born in Missouri, the son of a Missouri River pilot, Twain traveled nationally and abroad before joining the newspaper business. After the success of his second book, he focused primarily on public speaking until he died of a heart attack.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Parks.
output: Rosa Parks (1913-2005) was a civil-rights activist known as the "mother of the modern civil rights movement." Parks worked as a seamstress in Montgomery, Alabama and was active in the NAACP. In December 1955, she refused to give up her seat on a bus to a white man, sparking a major boycott of the city's buses. She was arrested and ultimately found guilty, but the case became a rallying point in the civil rights movement, inspiring other boycotts and protests. Parks' legacy includes the Congressional Gold Medal and the Rosa Parks Highway.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Parks.
output: Rosa Parks (born 1913) was an African American civil rights activist who refused to give her bus seat to a white passenger in 1955, beginning the Montgomery, Alabama bus boycott. After a short arrest, the Montgomery Bus Boycott was successful and Parks became a national face of the civil rights movement. In 1958, she founded the Montgomery NAACP and a year later joined the newly formed National Association of Seat Reservers for Women. She also became the secretary under Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in his Montgomery chapter. After studying at a secretarial school in Detroit, Parks spent years as a receptionist at a Montgomery department store, where she was encouraged by a boss to work in secretarial school. Her refusal on the bus led to her arrest and sparked the Civil Rights Movement, thus leading to the 1955 Montgomery bus boycott that led black and white demonstrators to walk together to protest segregation. input: Write a short biography of Rosa Parks.
output: Rosa Parks (1913-2005) was a civil rights activist and key figure in the movement to end racial segregation. She was arrested in Montgomery, Alabama after refusing to give up her seat to a white man in December 1955. Over the next 381 days, 50,000 African Americans boycotted Montgomery’s public transit system. Rosa Parks played a pivotal role in the 1955 Montgomery bus boycott and the civil rights movement. She was inspired by Mohandas Gandhi's example and Martin Luther King Jr. hailed her as "the first lady of civil rights."

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Parks.
output: Rosa Parks (1913-2005) was a civil rights activist in the United States. She refused to give up her seat to a white passenger on a segregated bus in Montgomery, Alabama in 1955. Parks' action sparked the Montgomery Bus Boycott, which lasted 381 days. Her subsequent arrest during the boycott drew national attention to the civil rights movement. Parks became a leading activist in the Montgomery chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP). In 1965, she went to Detroit to work for the NAACP. In 1968, she became an independent political activist and lived in Detroit until her death in 2005. A crater on the far side of the moon is named after Parks.

input: Write a short biography of Novak Djokovic.
output: Novak Djokovic (born 1987), originally born in Serbia, moved to Monte Carlo in Monaco at the age of 12. He began playing serious tennis at age 14, taking up the sport after a relative introduced him to it. Djokovic is ranked the No. 1 singles player in the world, and holds the record for the most ATP Tour Masters 1000 titles. He is also the only man in the Open Era to win four consecutive majors on three different surfaces, winning the Australian, French, and US Open in 2015 after his Wimbledon win in 2014. He won the Australian Open and Wimbledon in 2016 as well, breaking his own record for the number of consecutive major titles. Djokovic won a gold medal at the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio.

A close ally of her father, Jawaharlal Nehru, Indira served as his Prime Minister after his death in 1964. She continued to work with the opposition Congress party, winning re-election as Prime Minister in 1971 and 1977. Indira then moved to the right, leading her party to nationalize major industries in 1969. A powerful military leader, Indira became prime minister again while also holding the defense portfolio. In 1975, she imposed a state of emergency, suspending civil liberties. The government faced serious rioting until Indira lifted the restrictions months later. A staunch nationalist, she led India to victory in the 1971 war despite military setbacks.

input: Write a short biography of Amelia Earhart.
output: Amelia Earhart (1897-1937) was an American aviation pioneer. She was the first woman to fly across the Atlantic and the first to make a solo flight in all four hemispheres. Earhart helped found the Ninety-Nines, an organization of women pilots. Before her disappearance, Earhart was hailed as a heroine of the women's rights movement. input: Write a short biography of Tina Turner.
output:
Tina Turner (born Annie Mae Bullock) is a Grammy Award-winning American singer, dancer, and actress. The daughter of Mississippi sharecroppers, she grew up in St. Louis, Missouri. After performing with Ike Turner in Kings of Rhythm and Ike and Tina Turner Revue, she became a solo star. Her hits included "Nutbush City Limits" and "Steamy Window," and her albums include Workin' Together (1998) and Simply the Best (1991). She is considered "Rock
and Roll's First Lady" and one of the greatest live performers of all time. Turner lives part-time in Switzerland.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.
output: Rosa Luxemburg (1870-1919) was a German Marxist theorist and writer killed by German militarists following the 1918 revolutions spreading throughout Eastern Europe. Her most famous work was The Accumulation of Capital, published posthumously in 1914; it argued for a shorter version of Karl Marx's vision of capitalism, with the state interfering in the economy to promote the interests of the working classes. After the First World War, Luxemburg was one of the socialist leaders pushing for a socialist state rather than a capitalist one.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.
output: Rosa Luxemburg (1870-1919) was a socialist writer and political theorist who became an important member of Germany's Social Democratic Party in 1898. Luxemburg worked as a journalist throughout her political career, including writing and participating in editorials in Die Neue Zeit, the SPD's theoretical journal, which was edited by Karl Kautsky. Luxemburg was instrumental in the Spartacist Uprising of 1919, a military uprising intended to overthrow the weak Weimar Republic government. Arrested for her role in the uprising, she eventually became a target of the Nazis and was murdered. Her writings and revolutionary activities led her to be considered one of the greatest political theorists of the 20th century.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.
output: Rosa Luxemburg (1871-1919) was a German socialist and revolutionary writer. She studied at the University of Zoller, a Marxist organization, graduating in 1896 with an economics degree. Luxemburg became an activist and editor of the Party of German Socialists Journal (Einheit), where she met her future collaborator Karl Liebknecht. A radical influence on the First International, Luxemburg worked and socialists in the Russian Revolution and was imprisoned by the Bolsheviks in 1913. After working in the Russian Civil War, Luxemburg returned to Germany. In 1919, she founded the Spartacus League, a revolutionary socialist party, but was arrested in January 1919. She was murdered by right-wing militia and her body was never found. The German Socialist Party and Spartacus League merged into the German Communist Party. She was an influential Marxist theorist and a radical voice for the international Socialist movement.

input: Write a short biography of Bob Marley.

input: Write a short biography of Bob Marley.
output: Robert Nesta "Bob" Marley (1945-1981) was a Jamaican singer-songwriter who rose to international fame in the 1970s with the album Catch a Fire, which explored the sociopolitical issues of African countries such as Ethiopia. He helped popularize reggae music, a fusion of Caribbean genres, with hits like "No Woman No Cry." Marley's songs featured a Rastafarian faith, using reggae to explore topics such as religious oppression, imperialism, and black pride. After his debut studio album in 1974, Marley went on to record more albums, win five Grammys, and become regarded as one of the most iconic musicians of all time.

input: Write a short biography of Bob Marley.
output: Robert Nesta Marley (1945-1981) was a Jamaican musician and social activist, who spearheaded the international reggae music movement. Marley began his career as lead vocalist of the duo The Wailers with Peter Tosh and Bunny Wailer. Marley formed the band Bob Marley and the Wailers with the addition of Jamaican musicians Ernest Ranglin and Junior Braithwaite. Marley's lyrics dealt with themes of spirituality, racial unity, social equality, and political dissent. He died of lung cancer in 1981. His legacy was a powerful influence on the Rastafari movement and reggae music more broadly. At the 2001 Grammy Awards, Marley's "No Woman, No Cry" won Record of the Year, Best Reggae Album, and Song of the Year.
